parts.label: (i)

content.text: On Fig. 1.1, take two readings from the metre rule to determine the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the coiled part of the spring

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Draw a diagram to show clearly how you would use a set square to obtain an accurate reading from the metre rule
The student suspends a load of \(P = 1.0 \text{N}\) from the spring
He records the new length \(l_{1}\) of the coiled part of the spring
cm
Calculate the extension \(e_{1}\) using the equation \(e_{1} = (l_{1} - l_{0})\)
Calculate a value for the spring constant \(k\) of the spring using the equation
Include the unit
k =
The student suspends a load of \(P = 5.0 \text{N}\) from the spring
He records the new length \(l_{5}\) of the coiled part of the spring
cm
Calculate the extension \(e_{5}\) using the equation \(e_{5} = (l_{5} - l_{0})\)
Calculate a second value for the spring constant \(k\) of the spring using the equation
Give your answer to two significant figures
k =
State whether your two values of the spring constant \(k\) can be considered equal within the limits of experimental accuracy
Explain your answer by referring to your results
statement
explanation
Suggest the additional apparatus that the student uses
Suggest how the student uses the additional results
A student improves the experiment by taking additional sets of readings
A student investigates the stretching of a spring
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1
The thermometer in Fig. 2.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
The student pours hot water into the metal can
She places the thermometer in the hot water
She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately starts a stop-clock
She measures the water temperature every 30 s. The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
State two precautions taken when reading the volume of water in a measuring cylinder in order to obtain an accurate result
The student records the volume \(V\) to the nearest \(1 \text{cm}^3\)
Suggest why this is appropriate
The student pours the water from the can into a measuring cylinder and records the volume \(V\) of water
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) of the hot water between times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 60 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R_{1}\) of the water using the equation
where \(\Delta t = 60 \text{s}\). Include the unit
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) of the hot water between times \(t = 120 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R_{2}\) of the water using the equation
where \(\Delta t = 60 \text{s}\). Include the unit
A student suggests that the rate of cooling is lower when the temperature of the water is lower
State and explain whether the results support this suggestion
The student states that most of the thermal energy lost by the water in the can is by evaporation from the water surface
Another student states that most of the thermal energy lost by the water in the can is by conduction through the sides of the can
The students repeat the experiment twice to investigate the two statements
Suggest **one** suitable addition to the apparatus for **each** additional experiment
A student investigates the cooling of water
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1
The student measures the current and decides that he wants to use a lower current
He adds a variable resistor to the circuit to reduce the current
On Fig. 3.1, mark with an \(\mathbf{X}\) a suitable position in the circuit for the variable resistor
The student measures the current \(I\) in the circuit
Record the current shown in Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.3
The student places the sliding contact at a distance \(l = 85.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\)
He measures, and records in Table 3.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the length \(l\) of resistance wire \(\mathbf{BC}\)
Record, in Table 3.1, the potential difference shown in Fig. 3.3
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(85.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire using the equation
Complete the column headings in Table 3.1
The student repeats the procedure using \(l\) values of \(65.0 \text{cm}\), \(45.0 \text{cm}\), \(25.0 \text{cm}\) and \(5.0 \text{cm}\). His readings are shown in Table 3.1
Plot a graph of resistance \(R\) (\(y\)-axis) against length \(l\) (\(x\)-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)

parts.label: (f)

content.text: Use your graph to determine the resistance \(R_{50}\) of \(50.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information

content.text: A student investigates the resistance of a wire
Fig. 3.1 shows the circuit he uses
A student investigates the force required to break different beams made from a mixture of sand and cement. All the beams have the same cross-section
Plan an experiment to investigate the force required to break the beams
Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up
The following apparatus is available:

a selection of beams made from different ratios of sand and cement and of various lengths
triangular blocks to support the beams
a metre rule
a selection of loads.
